result.execSummary:
The defendant Joshua R. Bella was found guilty of the following charge(s) in this case. One or more other charges in this case were dismissed. The dismissed charges were not proven and have no legal effect. Joshua R. Bella is presumed innocent of the dismissed charges. On one or more other charges, Joshua R. Bella was found not guilty. These charges were not proven and have no legal effect. Joshua R. Bella is presumed innocent of the not guilty charges.

  • Joshua R. Bella was found guilty of Attempt 1st-Degree Intentional Homicide [Modifiers: Repeater, Use Dangerous Weapon (Felony 5+ Yrs)], a class B felony, Wisconsin Statutes 940.01(1)(a).
  • Joshua R. Bella was found guilty of Battery with Substantial Risk of Great Bodily Harm [Modifiers: Habitual Criminality, Use Dangerous Weapon (Felony 5+ Yrs)], a class H felony, Wisconsin Statutes 940.19(6).
  • Joshua R. Bella was found guilty of Burglary-Armed w/ Dangerous Weapon [Modifiers: Repeater], a class E felony, Wisconsin Statutes 943.10(2)(a).

Notice to employers: It may be a violation of state law to discriminate against a job applicant because of an arrest or conviction record. Generally speaking, an employer may refuse to hire an applicant on the basis of a conviction only if the circumstances of the conviction substantially relate to the particular job. For more information, see Wisconsin Statute 111.335 and the Department of Workforce Development's publication, Arrest and Conviction Records under the Law.

superMiscConds.notes: If discharged with outstanding financial obligations, a civil Judgment will be entered against the Defendant in favor of restitution victims and/or governmental entities for the balance due. All available enforcement actions will be used to collect the debt. Per Wisconsin Statute, funds from prison accounts may be used for obligations in accordance with prison policy not to exceed 50% of gross.Pay all court ordered financial obligations in full 90 days prior to discharge, but set up a payment plan and the financial obligations of prison wages as determined by the Department of Corrections.
Obtain and maintain full-time employment or schooling or a combination of both equaling full-time as medically able to do so.
No possession or use of dangerous weapons including swords, knives, or other similar bladed-type instruments, unless it is with the agent's prior permission.
No contact with J.R., his residence, or place of employment.

Not eligible for the challenge program.
Not eligible for substance abuse.
Maintain absolute sobriety for the term of this sentence.
Not to be on the premises of taverns, bars, liquor stores, or other establishments where the primary source of income is from the sale and/or distribution of alcoholic beverages.
Comply with any other assessments, treatment, or programming that is deemed appropriate by the Compas assessment and the Department of Corrections.
Sign release of information forms for offender's assessments, medication/pharmacy(ies) and/or treatment so the agent can monitor compliance.
Provide DNA sample for testing if not already completed.
Comply with any other monitoring of alcohol intake the Department may request, which may include UA.

    IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that Attorney Lane Fitzgerald is relieved of further representing Joshua Bella in this matter.  See WIS STAT 809.32(3)
    IT IS FURTHER ORDERED that this summary disposition order will not be published.

records.addlTxt:
Defendant Joshua R. Bella in court with attorney Rodman Wells Streicher. Defendant Joshua R. Bella in custody. Louis John Molepske appeared for the State of Wisconsin.

2:47 pm  Court calls the case.

Court has received the Department of Corrections Pre-Sentence Investigation and provided a copy to the parties.
Court notes two corrections to make.
Atty Molepske does not have any other corrections.
Atty Streicher notes two corrections.

Victim makes statements to the Court.

Atty Molepske makes sentencing arguments to the Court.
Atty Streicher makes sentencing arguments to the Court.

BY THE COURT: 

Count 1:
Determinate Prison Sentence of 32 years - 17 years Initial Confinement and 15 years Extended Supervision, consecutive to sentence currently serving
Not eligible for the challenge program.
Not eligible for substance abuse.
Jail credit - 22 days served
Conditions:
Pay restitution to the victim in the amount of $10,971.07.
No contact with J.R., his residence, or place of employment.
No possession or use of dangerous weapons including swords, knives, or other similar bladed-type instruments, unless it is with the agent's prior permission.
Maintain absolute sobriety for the term of this sentence.
Not to be on the premises of taverns, bars, liquor stores, or other establishments where the primary source of income is from the sale and/or distribution of alcoholic beverages.
Comply with any other assessments, treatment, or programming that is deemed appropriate by the Compas assessment and the Department of Corrections.
Sign release of information forms for offender's assessments, medication/pharmacy(ies) and/or treatment so the agent can monitor compliance.
Pay all court ordered financial obligations in full 90 days prior to discharge, but set up a payment plan and the financial obligations of prison wages as determined by the Department of Corrections.
Obtain/maintain employment and/or schooling or a combination of both equal to full time as medically able to do so.
Provide DNA sample for testing if not already completed.
Comply with any other monitoring of alcohol intake the Department may request, which may include UA.
Pay court costs and applicable surcharges, including the DNA Surcharge.

Count 3:
Determinate Prison Sentence of 5 years - 3 years Initial Confinement and 2 years Extended Supervision, concurrent to Count 1 and consecutive to any other sentence currently serving
Not eligible for the challenge program.
Not eligible for substance abuse.
Jail credit - 22 days served
Conditions: Same conditions as Count 1.
Pay court costs and applicable surcharges, including the DNA Surcharge.

Count 4:
Determinate Prison Sentence of 11 years - 8 years Initial Confinement and 3 years Extended Supervision, concurrent to Counts 1 and 3 and consecutive to any other sentence currently serving
Not eligible for the challenge program.
Not eligible for substance abuse.
Jail credit - 22 days served
Conditions: Same conditions as Count 1 and Count 3.
Pay court costs and applicable surcharges, including the DNA Surcharge.

Atty Streicher questioned the Court re: if gifts would be taken out of the prison account for restitution.
Court responds.
Attorneys will keep their PSI's confidential.
Atty Streicher to go over appeallate rights with his client.
Written Explanation of Determinate Sentence is provided to the attorneys.
Ad Prosequendum with attached Writ of Habeas Corpus Ad Prosequendum /s/ TBE 03/14/17

records.addlTxt: PSI Report dated 03-03-17

Exhibits Filed on 01/25/17:  #P1, #P2, #P3, #P4, #P5, #P6, #P7, #P8, #P9, #P10, #P13, #P14, #P16, #P17, #P18 (not scanned)
Exhibits Filed on 01/26/17:  #P19, #P20, #P21, #P22, #P23, #P24, #P25, #P26, #P27, #P28, #P29, #P30, #P31,#P32, #P33, #P34, #P35, #P36  (copy of poster board)
Exhibits Filed on 01/27/16:  #P38 & #P39

And Exhibits 1 - 40 except:
Exhibits P11 Red Handle Sword (stored at Stevens Point PD)
Exhibits P12 Red handled sword in sheath (stored at Stevens Point PD)
Exhibits P15 Blood stained pants in bag (stored at Stevens Point PD)
Exhibit P36 - Aerial photo poster board size (stored at Clerk of Courts)

- Jury Questions
- Exhibit Transfer Sheets
Questions from the Juror's with response from the Court
Memo indicating that specific exhibits have been given to the Law Enforcement Agency as stated - dated 01/25/17 and 01/27/17
Minutes from Verdict held on 01/30/17
Exhibit #D40 - Medical Packet marked as "sealed"

Day 4: 8:10 AM DA Louis Molepske, Jr is present for the State and Atty Rodman Wells Streicher is present, Defendant Joshua Bella is present.
Packet of pictures are given to the Court prior to the start of Court.

8:19 AM Court calls case, outside the presence of the Jurors.
Atty Molepske states appearances. 
Day 4 is about to start.
Jury deliberated for a while on Friday and were asked to come back today. 
Court received a note from the jury, requesting all the picture evidence. Court is prepared to send back Exhibits: 1-8, 10, 13, 14, 16, 17, 19-35, as well as the posterboard and Exhibits 38 and 39.

8:22 AM All 12 jurors have returned to the Courtroom. Court will send all photos back to the jury as well as Exhibit 36. Court addresses the Jurors, jury must reach a verdict unanimously. Once verdict has been reached, Foreperson is to notify the Bailiff.  Jury instructions will also be returned to Jurors. 

One Juror addresses the feedback in the microphone. Court will turn the microphone off and on, to eliminate the feedback. 

8:24 AM Jurors have left the courtroom. Neither party has anything else to put on the record. Court addresses the parties that intake is being held in here today.  

11:17 AM Court is back on the record.
Same appearances are the same. 
Court has received a number of notes from the Jury this morning. 
Court reads first note. Was handled this morning.
Court reads second note. 2 additional copies of jury instructions  were sent back.
Court reads third note. 2 additional copies of the juryinstructions  were sent back.
Court reads fourth note, requesting white board/easel.  Court will send an easel with paper/markers. 
11:19 AM Court is in recess.
Defendant Joshua R. Bella in court with attorney Rodman Wells Streicher. Louis John Molepske appeared for the State of Wisconsin.
4:58 p.m.  Court calls the case. 
Atty Molepske appears with Detective Zblewski. 
Defendant appears in person with Atty Streicher. 
Court has been advised the jury has reached a verdict. 
4:59 p.m.  Jurors are escorted to the courtroom.  
Court reads the verdict. 

The jury finds: 
Count 1 - Guilty of Attempted 1st Degree Homicide as charged in count 1 of the amended information. 
Did he commit the crime while using a dangerous weapon?  Answer: Yes.

Count 2 - Not Guilty of 1st Degree Reckless Injury. 

Count 3 - 
Guilty of Battery with Substantial Risk of Great Bodily Harm 940.19(6)
Did he commit the crime while using a dangerous weapon?  Answer: Yes. 

Not Guilty of Aggravated Battery. 

Count 4 - Guilty of Armed Burglary as charged in Count 4 of the amended information. 
Did he commit the crime while using a dangerous weapon?  Answer: Yes.

Court conducts a sidebar with the attorneys. 

Court individually polls the jury at this time. 

5:07 p.m.  Court thanks the jury for their service and discharges them at this time.  
Court states Count 3 did return verdict forms on 2 of the 3 forms they were given.  They found him guilty of the lesser included offense and then completed the verdict for the original charge of aggravated battery.  
Atty Molepske asks for judgment on the verdict. 
Atty Streicher does not object. 
BY THE COURT:  Court orders judgment on the verdict. 
Bond is revoked. 
Court orders Pre-Sentence Investigation. 
PSI to be completed by 3/8/17.  
  Sentencing hearing scheduled for March 17, 2017 at 02:45 pm.
Sentencing hearing on March 17, 2017 at 02:45 pm.

Day 3:
8:44 a.m. DA Louis Molepske, Jr is present for the State and Atty Rodman Wells Streicher is present, Defendant Joshua Bella is present.
 Court calls case, and states appearances.  Court states he did meet with the attorneys yesterday regarding Jury Instructions.  Counsel has received copies of the Modified Jury Instructions.  Atty Molepske makes statements regarding the Jury Instructions.

8:46 a.m.  Jurors return to the Courtroom.  Court states all 14 Jurors are present.
8:48 a.m.  Witness J. D. is called, sworn and examined by Atty Molepske.  Exhibit #37 is marked, and used during testimony.
8:56 a.m.  Atty Streicher requests a side bar. 
Examination continues.  Exhibits #38 and #39 are marked, identified by the witness, and used during testimony.
9:07 a.m.  Atty Streicher requests a side bar.
9:08 a.m.  Court states the Court needs to hear an argument regarding an objection, and states the Jurors will need to return to the Jury Room.  
Court states for the record that the Jurors have left the Courtroom.
9:09 a.m.  Atty Streicher states his objection.  Atty Molepske makes arguments regarding the objection.  Atty Streicher withdraws his objection.
Court addresses the first side bar.

9:14 a.m.  Jurors return to the Courtroom.  Examination by Atty Molepske continues.  Exhibits #19, #20, #22 and #24 are used during testimony.
9:30 a.m.  Atty Molepske requests the Court Officer to help assist him with presenting Exhibits #11 and #12 to the witness.  Court will allow.
9:34 a.m.  Atty Molepske states the Court Officer has to leave the Courtroom at this time, and requests that Exhibits #11, #12 and #15 which are in the custody of A. Zblewski, be removed from the Courtroom while he is gone.   No objection by Atty Streicher.
Examination continues.

9:49 a.m.  Cross examination by Atty Streicher.  
10:03 a.m.  Atty Molespke requests a side bar.  Court will excuse the Jurors from the Courtroom, so some legal issues may be discussed.
Court notes for the record, that the Jurors have left the Courtroom.
Atty Molepske states his objection.

10:08 a.m.  Jurors return to the Courtroom.  
Court states for the record that all 14 Jurors have returned to the Courtroom.
Cross examination continues. 
10:12 a.m.  Redirect by Atty Molepske.
Atty Molepske offers Exhibits #37, #38 and #39.  No objection.  Court receives.
Atty Molepske requests Exhibits #38 and #39 be published to the Jury.  No objection.  Court states these Exhibits may be published to the Jury.  Atty Molepske asks that Exhibits #21 and #23 be republished to the Jury, as they now have additional marks.  No objection.  Court states they may be republished to the Jury.
10:21 a.m.  Redirect by Atty Molepske.
10:22 a.m.  Recross by Atty Streicher.
10:23 a.m.  Redirect by Atty Molepske.
10:24 a.m.  Witness is excused.  Atty Molepske states witness may be released from the subpeona.  Atty Molepske states he has no futher witnesses.

10:25 a.m.  Court states the Jurors may take a recess, and will resume in about 20 minutes.
10:26 a.m.  Jurors leave the Courtroom.
10:27 a.m.  Atty Molespke states all Exhibits have been offered and received.  Atty Molepske states the State will rest.

Court questions if the Defendant will be testifying.  Atty Streicher discusses this with Atty Molepske and his client.

10:30 a.m. In regards to the Defendant testifying, Court states the attorneys have conferred, and Atty Streicher has conferred with the Defendant .  Atty Streicher states the Defendant will not take the stand.  Court questions the Defendant regarding his right to testify.

10:32 a.m.  Court will recess until 10:45 a.m.
10:54 a.m.  Court states we are back on the record.  Court states appearances are as before, outside the Jurors.  Court states A. Zblewski has returned to the Courtroom.  Atty Molepske makes statements regarding the next witness' possible testimony.

10:56 a.m.  Jurors return to the Courtroom.  
Court notes for the record, that all 14 Jurors have returned.
10:58 a.m. Witness J. R. is called, sworn by the Clerk and direct examination by Atty Streicher.  Exhibit #40 is marked, and used during testimony. 
11:14 a.m.  Cross examination by Atty Molepske.  Exhibit #23, #39, #38 are used during testimony. 
11:30 a.m.  Redirect by Atty Streicher.
11:33 a.m.  Recross by Atty Molepske.
11:33 a.m.  Redirect by Atty Molepske.
Witness is excused.  
11:34 a.m.  Defense rests.

Court advises the Jurors regarding the Jury Instructions.  
Court will allow the Jurors to recess until 1:00 p.m.  Court instuctions the Jurors not to discuss this case.
11:35 a.m.  Jurors leave the Courtroom.  
Court states the record is to reflect the Jurors have left the Courtroom.

Court addresses the Attorneys regarding the Jury Instructions. 
Atty Molepske motions the Court to dismiss Count 5.  No objection. 
Court will grant the Motion to Dismiss Count 5. 
Further discussions regarding the instructions.  Discussion regarding a lesser charge. 
Attorneys discuss the request outside the presence of the Court.  
Atty Streicher makes statements regarding the charge of Aggreviated Battery.
Atty Molepske makes statements.
Court makes statements how the Jury could convict the Defendant on the lesser charge, or on the Aggreviated Battery.  
Atty Streicher states the Defendant indicates he would have plead to the lesser charge.
Discussion regarding if that was offered.
Court will give the Jury Instruction of the charge, along with the lesser charge.
Atty Molepske makes statements regarding if there was previous offers.  

11:57 a.m.  Court prints out the Jury Instructions for the Attorney to review. 
Atty Molepske makes statements regarding the charges.  
Court makes statements regarding how it was charged. 
Court states modifications to the Instructions.   
Further review of the Instructions.  

12:11 p.m.  Court will try to have the Instructions amended by 12:45 p.m. in time for the Attorneys to review.
12:12 p.m. Court is in recess.



Clerk is now MP

Attys are provided with copies of the completed Jury Instructions.
1:30 p.m. Court is back on the record and states the appearances are as previously stated.
Jury instructions have been changed to include the lesser charge. Verdict form has also been changed.  
Court takes a moment to review the jury instructions and states there may be language missing. Court instructs the Attys to review the rest of the instructions.
Court needs to modify the instructions to include the section on intent in regards to Jury Instruction 1225. 
Court reviews the modifications to the instructions with the Attorneys.

1:43 p.m. Court will take a break to correct the jury instructions.

1:49 p.m. Court is back on the record. Attys review the jury instructions. No objections from either Atty.

1:51 p.m.  All 14 Jurors are escorted back in the Courtroom. Court welcomes them back to the Courtroom and informs them that Count 5 has been dismissed and they will not be rendering a verdict on Count 5.

1:52 p.m. Court reads Opening Jury Instructions to the Jurors.

2:28 p.m. DA Molepske gives closing arguments. 

3:03 p.m. Atty Streicher gives closing arguments.

3:21 p.m. DA Molepske gives his rebuttal.

3:27 p.m. Court addresses the Jury.

3:36 p.m. Jurors 1037 and 1123 are excused.  Clerk administers Oath of Officers. Jurors are escorted from the Courtroom to begin deliberations.

3:37 p.m. Court is in recess.

3:40 p.m. Court is back on the record to discuss which Exhibits Jurors may see. Exhibits # 9 & #37 are not to be taken back to the Jurors. If Jurors wish to view Exhibits # 11, #12 & #15 may only be visible in the Courtroom.  The rest of the Exhibits are available for the Jurors examination.

3:49 p.m. Court is back in recess.

Clerk is now K.S. 

4:35 p.m. Court is back in session outside the presence of the jury. 
Atty Molepske, Atty Streicher and the defendant are present.  
Court reads the first question of the jury for the parties. 

Exhibits #36 will be provided to the jury at this time.  
Court states response for the parties.  
Neither party objects to the response. 
Court reads the written response to the jury. 
Neither party objects. 
Court reads second question of the jury. 
Atty Molepske makes statements to the Court. 
Atty Streicher makes statements to the Court. 
Court provides copy of the written note and response for the parties to review. 
Neither party objects. 

BY THE COURT:  Exhibit #40 is to be sealed and notes it has not been admitted into evidence. 

4:59 p.m.  Court is back in recess. 
Atty Molepske, Atty Streicher and the defendant are present. 
Court reads the question of the jury. 
Court reads the response to the jury. 
Atty Molespke makes statements to the Court. 
Atty Streicher makes statements to the Court. 
Court provides copy of the written note and response for the parties to review. 
Neither party objects. 

5:02 p.m.  Court is back in recess. 

5:55 p.m . Court is back in session outside the presence of the jury. 
Atty Molepske, Atty Streicher and the defendant are present. 
Court has been advised that the jury is still deliberating.  Court sent 2 notes, one requesting water and the other asking to make the phone call to her daycare. 
Neither party objects to those.  
Court will bring the jury in and excuse them for the weekend and advise them to return at 8:00 a.m. on Monday. 
5:57 p.m. Jurors are escorted to the Courtroom. 
Court questions the jurors re: returning on Monday morning at 8:00 a.m.  
Court advises the jury not to discuss the matter with anyone or amongst themselves until they return on Monday.  Do not listen to media or conduct research on the matter. 
5:58 p.m.  Jurors are escorted from the Courtroom. 

6:00 p.m.  Court is in recess. 
All exhibits are collected and accounted for.
(Count amended to lesser charge - Jury Verdict)

Day 2:
8:41 a.m. DA Louis Molepske, Jr is present for the State and Atty Rodman Wells Streicher is present, Defendant Joshua Bella is present.
Court calls the case. DA Molepske states appearances, which are the same as January 25, 2017. 
Court questions if Attys have had a chance to review the jury instuctions.
DA Molepske states there is an error in the verdict form, the word attempted is used and it should not be.
Court agrees.
DA Molepske objects jury instuction number 247.
Court states as trial is not concluded as of yet and will rule on number 247 once case is concluded.
DA Molepske makes statements regarding a witness.
Atty Streicher responds.
DA Molepske responds.
Atty Streicher responds.

BY THE COURT:
The witness is not to mention his profession.
 
8:52 a.m. All 14 juror's have returned and the parties are ready to proceed.  Clerk swears in Officer Brooks. Direct examination by DA Molepske.  Exhibits #19 - # 24 are marked for the State. 
Court stops testimony to fix sound equipment.
8:57 a.m. Direct examination of Officer Brooks continues.  Exhibits #14, #16, #17 are referred to during testimony. Exhibits #19 - 24 are referred to during testimony. DA Molepske moves Exhibits #19 - 24 into evidence. No objection from Atty Streicher. 

BY THE COURT:
Exhibits #19 - 24 are admitted into evidence.

DA Molepske moves to publish the exhibits to the Jury. No objection from Atty Streicher.

BY THE COURT:
Exhibits may be published to the Jury.

Jury reviews the exhibits. Direct examination continues. 9:13 a.m. Cross examination by Atty Streicher.  Exhibits #19 - #24 are referred to during cross examination. 9:24 a.m. Re-direct by DA Molepske.  9:27 a.m. Re-cross by Atty Streicher.  Exhibits #25 & #26 are marked for Atty Streicher and are referred to during testimony.  Witness is excused.

9:31 a.m. Clerk swears in J. R. Direct examination by DA Molepske. J.R. identifies the defendant in the Courtroom. Atty Streicher requests a sidebar.  9:41 a.m. Direct examination continues by DA Molepske.  Exhibits #16, #17, #19 - #24 are referred to during testimony.  10:08 a.m. Atty Streicher requests to take morning break prior to Cross-examination.  Jurors are excorted from the Courtroom..

10:10 a.m. Court is in recess.  

10:26 a.m. Court is back on the record and appearances are as previously stated. All Jurors are escorted back into the Courtroom. J.R. is still on the stand and is still under oath. Cross examination by Atty Streicher.  Exhibits #19 - #26 are referred to during testimony. 10:44 a.m. Re-direct by DA Molepske. 10:52 a.m. Re-cross by Atty Streicher. Exhibits #27 - #31 are marked for Atty Streicher and referred to during testimony.  10:58 a.m. Re-direct by DA Molepske.  10:59 a.m. Re-cross by Atty Streicher. Witness is excused.

11:00 a.m. Clerk swears in J. C. DA Molepske requests J.R. be released from his subpeona so he may be in the Courtroon.  No objection from Atty Streicher.  
BY THE COURT:
J.R. is released from his subpeona.

11:01 a.m. Direct examination of J.C. by DA Molepske.  J.C. identifies the Defendant in the Courtroom.  Exhibits #14, #16, & #17 are referred to during testimony. 11:18 a.m. Cross examination by Atty Streicher.  11:22 a.m. Re-direct by DA Molepske.  Witness is excused and released from his subpeona.

11:26 a.m.  Clerk swears in N.B. DIrect examination by DA Molepske.  Witness identifies Defendant in the Courtroom.  Exhibit #1 is referred to during testimony.  11:37 a.m. Cross examination by Atty Streicher.  11:42 a.m. Re-direct by DA Molepske.  11:43 a.m. Re-cross by Atty Streicher.  Witness is excused and released from her subpeona.

11:47 a.m. Court instructs the Jurors to be back by 1:00 p .m. Court instructs the Jurors to not discuss the case until the case has concluded. Jurors have left the courtroom.
Court addresses sidebar that happened while J.R. was on the witness stand. 

11:52 a.m. Court is in recess for lunch. Attys are advised to be back by 1:10 p.m.

************Clerk is now A.Z.**********
1:14 PM Court calls case.
Court states appearances.
Court is in session without Jury at this time. 

Atty Molepske addresses the Court with regards to the next two witnesses.
Atty Streicher addresses the Court, gives reply.
Discussion continues as to verbage. 

Court addresses the parties. 

BY THE COURT:
Court finds that witness may testify as what was stated on the record.

1:20 PM All Jurors have returned to the Courtroom.

1:21 PM J. Moon is called and sworn in.
Direct examination by Atty Molepske.
Witness identifies Defendant.
1:25 PM Cross-examination by Atty Streicher. 
1:27 PM Witness is released from her subpoena.

1:28 PM N. Neuberger is called and sworn in.
Direct examination by Atty Molepske.
Witness identifies Defendant.
1:30 PM Cross-examination by Atty Streicher.
1:32 PM Re-direct by Atty Molepske.
1:33 PM Re-cross by Atty Streicher.

1:35 PM S. Linjer is called and sworn in.
Direct examination by Atty Molepske.
Witness identifies Defendant.
1:40 PM Cross-examination by Atty Streicher.
1:45 PM Witness is released from his subpoena.

1:46 PM A. Zblewski is called and sworn in.
Direct examination by Atty Molepske.
Exhibits #10, #27- #31 are referred to.
Exhibits #32-#36 are marked on behalf of Plaintiff, are referred to.
Exhibit #36 is offered and received, admitted.
2:10 PM Cross-examination by Atty Streicher.
Exhibits #26 - #30 are referred to.
Exhibits #25-#31 are offered and received. 
Exhibits #10, #32, #33, #34 and #35 are offered and received.
Exhibits #34, #32, #33,#10, #25, #31, #30, #29, #28, #27, and #26 are published to the Jury. (Exhibits given to Jury to review at this time).

2:25 PM Court will take an afternoon recess, 15 minutes.
Jurors are advised not to talk about this matter.
Jurors have left the Courtroom.
Neither party has anything to add on the record. 

2:43 PM Court is back on the record. Appearances are as they were before the recess. Jury is not in the courtroom. Det Zblewski stepped out and Det. Williams took his spot.

Exhibits #1, #2, #3, #8 and #17 are offered and received.

Exhibits #19, #20, #21, #22, #23, and #24 are questioned, they have been published to the Jury this morning.

2:47 PM All Jurors return to the Courtroom.

2:48 PM D. Williams is called and sworn in.
Direct examination by Atty Molepske.
Witness identifies Defendant.
3:07 PM Cross-examination by Atty Streicher.
3:12 PM Sidebar.
3:13 PM Cross-examination continues.
3:14 PM Re-direct by Atty Molepske.

3:14 PM Atty Molepske addresses the Court, has one more witness for tomorrow morning. Court advises Jurors to return at 8:30 AM tomorrow. Court reminds Jurors to not discuss matter with anyone.  There is an article in the SPJ today and Jurors are ordered to not look at the article.

3:15 PM Jurors are excused for the day. 
Jurors exit the Courtroom.

Court addresses the brief sidebar done previously, for the record. 

Parties are to reconviene to chambers to discuss jury instructions.
Parties are to be here at 8:20 PM.
 
All exhibits are accounted for except for #11, #12 and #15, which are in the property of the SPPD for storage.
Rescan of Exhibit #P9 Letters from Defendant to Michelle Braun (5)

Day 1:
DA Louis Molepske, Jr is present for the State and Atty Rodman Wells Streicher is present, Defendant Joshua Bella is present.
8:55 a.m.  Exhibit's #1-#8 pre-marked for Atty Molepske.
10:03 a.m.  Court calls case.
Atty Molepske states the appearances.
Hearing being held in Branch 3 prior to proceeding with the Jury Trial and out of the presence of the potential jurors.
Letter had been received by the Court on January 9, 2017, from the defendant, and provided to both attorneys.
Court questions Atty Streicher; Atty Streicher responds.
Atty Streicher makes statements.
Atty Streicher states his defendant is requesting additional time for himself, as the defense attorney, to interview specific witnesses.
Court questions the defendant.
Atty Molepske makes statements.
Court questions Atty Molepske regarding any credit card use (belonging to the defendant) by anyone other than himself.  Atty Molepske responds.
Court again questions the defendant.
Court questions Atty Molepske regarding "recordings" ; makes statements in regards to these "recordings".  
Atty Streicher makes additional statements.
10:19 a.m.  Court addresses the defendant's request for a continuance of this Jury Trial.
Atty Molepske makes his statements.
Court makes statements on the record in regards to the letter that had been filed on January 9, 2017 from the defendant.
Atty Streicher makes statement.
Atty Streicher states that he is prepared to proceed to trial today.
Defendant makes further statements.
Court makes statements to the defendant.
BY THE COURT:  Court DENIES the request for a continuance of this Jury Trial. Court will proceed with the trial starting today.  
Court questions the defendant if he is wanting to proceed today with his current attorney.  Defendant indicates that he is willing to proceed with the Jury Trial and represent himself.  Court questions the defendant again.  
Defendant will proceed with his current attorney.
Court informs the defendant that if he causes a disturbance that this jury trial will proceed, even if they have to take a brief delay in testimony.

BEGINNING OF JURY TRIAL - DAY ONE:
10:42 a.m.  Court thanks the juror's for their patience in waiting until the jury trial started.
Court calls the case.
Atty Molepske states the appearances.
Court welcomes the juror's and instructs them on how this jury trial will be proceeding.
10:50 a.m.  Clerk administer's Voir Dire Oath.
Potential juror's are called to the jury box.
Juror's chosen are:  1116, 1029, 1084, 1123, 1045, 1131, 1168, 1166, 1161, 1138, 1115, 1052, 1022, 1105, 1143, 1056, 1165, 1109, 1005, 1144, 1053, 1171, 1110 and 
1128.  There will be 12 juror's with 2 alternate's.
Court inform's the potential juror's of the charges against the defendant.
Court administer's Voir Dire.
Court may do an individual voir dire on Juror #1029, later on in the process.
11:07 a.m.  Court identifies the possible witnesses, to the potential juror's, that may be called during this jury trial.
11:28 a.m.  Juror #1171 is excused and replaced with Juror #1148.
11:33 a.m.  Atty Molepske administer's his voir dire.
11:51 a.m.  Court gives individual voir dire to juror #1143.
11:53 a.m.  Juror #1143 is excused and replaced with Juror #1027.
Court gives individual voir dire to Juror #1027.
Atty Molepske continues his voir dire.
12:07 p.m.  Atty Streicher administer's his voir dire.
12:31 p.m.  Court is in a brief recess.
12:35 p.m.  Individual voir dire on Juror #1029.
Court states the appearances - they remain the same as earlier stated.
Parties are in the jury room for the individual voir dire.
12:38 p.m  Atty Molepske administers individual voir dire.
Defendant is informed to speak with his attorney and not make any comments.
12:40 p.m  Atty Streicher administers individual voir dire.
12:41 p.m. Atty Streicher motions the Court to excuse Juror #1029.
BY THE COURT:  Due to the objective standard the Court will excuse Juror #1029 even though she did indicate that she would be fair and impartial.
12:45 p.m.  Court is back in session.
Appearances remain the same.
Juror #1029 is excused and replaced with Juror #1037.
Atty Molepske administers individual voir dire to Juror #1037.
Atty Streicher has no individual voir dire for this potential juror.
12:48 p.m.  Parties will exercise their peremptory strikes
While the parties do the peremptory strikes, Court inform's the potential jurors of what the remaining process may include
12:59 p.m. Clerk read's the names of the Juror's chosen to hear the Jury Trial -
1005, 1022, 1037, 1052, 1056, 1105, 1110, 1115, 1123, 1138, 1144, 1148, 1161 and 1165.
1:02 p.m.  Clerk administers Juror Oath.
1:03 p.m.  Court thanks all jurors not chosen and excuses them.
Court is in recess for lunch.
Attorney's are to return by 1:45 p.m.

Clerk:  ejp
2:00 p.m.  case is back on the record.  Appearances stated on the record.  
DA Molepske makes statement.  Attorney Streicher agrees with the statement of DA Molepske.  

2:04 p.m.  Jurors have returned to the courtroom - all 14 of them.  Court informs the jurors that they may take notes if they desire and the process for note taking.  
2:07 p.m.  DA Molepske gives his opening statement.  2:32 p.m.  Attorney Streicher gives opening statement.  
2:45 p.m.  Jurors are given notepads and pencils.  2:46 p.m.  Clerk swears in witness called by DA Molepske (M. B.).  DA examines the witness.  3:01 p.m.  Refers to Exhibit #9 in examination.  3:05 p.m.  Cross exam by Attorney Streicher.  3:08 p.m.  Objection by DA Molepske objection - Court sustains.  
3:10 p.m.  DA Molepske calls witness, clerk swears witness in (Sergeant M. Rottier).  DA examines the witness.  3:23 p.m.  Refers Exhibit #11 in examination.  3:27 p.m.  Exhibit #11 is displayed to the jury.  Exhibit #12 is referred to in examination.  Exhibit #12 is displayed to the jury.  3:32 p.m.  Examination continues by DA Molepske.  3:39 p.m.  Exhibits 1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, and 7 are referred to in examination.  3:46 p.m.  Refers to Exhibit #15 in examination.  3:46 p.m.  Exhibit #15 is displayed to the jury.  3:50 p.m. Exhibits 11, 12, 13, 14, 15, 16, 4, 5, 6, 7, 9 and 10 are admitted into evidence without objection by Attorney Streicher.  3:51 p.m.  Cross examination by Attorney Streicher.  4:00 p.m.  Redirect by DA Molepske.  Refers to Exhibit #7.  4:07 pm.  DA Molepske publishes exhibits to jurors.  4:07 p.m.  Recross by Attorney Streicher.  4:08 p.m.  Witness steps down and is excused from subpoena by Judge Eagon without objection.  4:11 p.m.  Clerk swears in the witness (T.B.)  DA Molepske examines the witness.  Refers to Exhibit #17, #18.  State plays Exhibit #18 to the jury.  Court does not require the court reporter to transcribe while the audio is being played.  State reads in the time recording.  Counter starts at 0:00 and stops 3 minutes 4 seconds.  Examination continues by DA Molepske.  4:40 p.m.  Cross exam by Attorney Streicher.  4:45 p.m.  Redirect by DA Molepske.  4:47 p.m.  Witness steps down.  
Court cautions the jurors to not discuss the case with anyone, no independent reseach, do no search on the internet.  4:48 p.m  Jurors are escorted out of the courtroom.  
The weapons will be returned to the custody of the Stevens Point Department.  Parties have been provided with proposed jury instructions so they may review in the morning.
Court is recess until 8:30 a.m.  Clerk accounts for all exhibits.
5:00 p.m court is in recess.

records.descr: Motion and order for withdrawal of counsel

records.addlTxt: Pre-trial conference at 11-23-2015 08:30 am

Defendant Joshua R. Bella in court with attorney Jay Kronenwetter. Defendant Joshua R. Bella in custody and appearing via videao from the Wisconsin State Prison System (Waupun). David Knaapen appears on behalf of Louis J. Molepske for the State of Wisconsin.
Case is set for a Motion for Withdrawal as Counsel.

2:47 p.m.  Court calls case.
Atty Knaapen states the appearances.
Court questions the defendant in regards to the dissatisfaction of representation he has received from his attorney.
Court makes further statements regarding the withdrawal of Atty Kronenwetter.
Court informs the defendant that the Jury Trial has been set for November 30, 2015.  Defendant indicates that he would like to get Public Defender representation.  
Court questions the defendant if he has made any additional attempts in obtaining counsel; defendant makes statements. 
Court questions defendant regarding a private attorney and the defendant has not contacted any attorney for representation.
Atty Kronenwetter makes statements regarding phone contact with defendant and informing the defendant that he was still his attorney of record and indicates that the defendant has filed information with the Office of Lawyer Regulation and Atty Kronenwetter indicates that he has to respond to their requests.
Atty Kronenwetter indicates that he cannot successfully represent the defendant.
Defendant makes statements that he agrees with Atty Kronenwetter that he does not want him to represent him in this case.
Court questions defendant if he can repair the attorney/client relationship; defendant makes statements.
Court makes further statements regarding the withdrawal of Atty Kronenwetter.
Defendant asks if the Court date can be extended.
Court informs the defendant that the Jury Trial will be postponed and that it will not be heard until next year.
Court further questions the defendant; defendant responds.
Court questions Atty Knaapen if they have a position on this case.
Atty Knaapen makes statements indicating that his concern would be that the defendant would not have any contact with Atty Kronenwetter's firm once he is allowed to withdraw.
Atty Kronenwetter makes statements.  
Defendant is still wishing that Atty Kronenwetter withdraw as counsel.
Court questions the defendant if he is eligible for the public defender if he would like them to represent him; defendant responds.
Court informs the defendant that he will not be allowed to keep extending this Jury Trial to obtain representation; defendant indicates he may want to obtain private counsel.
Defendant makes statements and court informs the defendant that these issues will not be heard at this hearing.

BY THE COURT:  
Court finds good cause for Atty Kronenwetter to withdraw as counsel.
Court signs the Order for Withdrawal of Counsel.
Atty Kronenwetter to contact the Public Defender's Office on behalf of the defendant to provide them with his address.

  Pre-trial conference scheduled for November 23, 2015 at 08:30 am.
Motion hearing at 11-04-2015 02:45 pm
and Affidavit of Atty Kronenwetter (unsigned order-hearing set)

Defendant Joshua R. Bella in court with attorney Jay Kronenwetter. Defendant Joshua R. Bella in custody. Louis J. Molepske appeared for the State of Wisconsin.

11:12 am. Court calls case.
State indicates they are ready to proceed with the trial.
Atty Kronenwetter makes statements.
Atty Kronenwetter has medical concerns in regards to Defendant.
Atty Kronenwetter requests the Court consider to extend the trial.
Court makes statements.
State makes statements in regards to length of witness list.
State indicates this matter might go into 3 days with deliberations.

State responds.

Court addresses information filed by the State.

BY THE COURT:
Court grants State's ability to amend the charge.

Defense waives reading and Defebdabt enters NOT GUILTY plea.

Court adds ct 2
Court finds Defendant's plea is freely, voluntarily and intelligently made.

BY THE COURT:
Court accepts NOT GUILTY plea to all counts to amended information.

Court addresses State's motion to add 911 call.
Defense has no objection to the State's motion.

BY THE COURT:
Court grants motion.

Court addresses State's motion to admit evidence from other crimes, wrongs or acts of defendant.
Atty Kronenwetter has no objection.

records.addlTxt: Jury trial on April 22, 2015 at 08:30 am.

Defendant Joshua R. Bella in court with attorney Jay Kronenwetter. Defendant Joshua R. Bella in custody. Louis J. Molepske appeared for the State of Wisconsin.

Atty Kronenwetter makes statements. Does not object to No. 1 in Motion in Limine. 

BY THE COURT:  Court orders all witnesses sequestered except for Detective Zblewski who will be allowed to be seated at the table as a representative of the State. 

Atty Kronenwetter makes statements re: convictions.
Atty Molepske makes statements re: witness convictions.  Will provide today. 

BY THE COURT:  
Court grants No. 4 pending subsequent motion by defendant contesting any of the 13.  If the defendant elects to testify and is asked how many convictions, the answer is 13.  
With regards to No. 3 - parties will discuss.  If no agreement, then a new hearing will be needed. 
BY THE COURT: No 5. is granted. 

Atty Kronenwetter makes statements re: Miranda Goodchild.
BY THE COURT: No 6.  Defendant will be admitted, pending proper foundation. 

Atty Kronenwetter does not object to No 7 with a caveat as stated.  
BY THE COURT:  No. 7. is granted; precluded from producing own out of court statement without proper foundation. 

Atty Kronenwetter does not object to No 8.
BY THE COURT:  No. 8 is granted.

Atty Kronenwetter makes statements re: state's witness and other acts.  
BY THE COURT: No. 9 is granted with exception of Nicole Bella, if there will be a motion re: other acts. 
Atty Molepske makes statements.  Received new information.  Will be provided to the defense. 

Atty Molepske makes statements re: No. 10. 
Atty Kronenwetter makes statements re: No. 10. 
Atty Molepske makes additional statements to the Court. 

Court questions parties re: No. 11. 
Atty Kronenwetter makes arguments to the Court. 
Atty Molepske makes arguments to the Court. 
BY THE COURT:  Court will withhold judgment on this issue. Potentionally a foundation or relevancy issue. 

Court questions Atty Kronenwetter re: motion to waive NGI. 
Atty Kronenwetter makes additional statements. 

Atty Molepske makes statements re: additional motions.  No jury instructions or witness list filed by the defense.  Asks the Court for some flexibility. 
Atty Kronenwetter makes statements.  
Atty Molepske makes statements re: jury instructions.  Asks the jury instruction for finding of intent be added. 
Court notes that is usually included in the substantive instruction for the defense. 

Court questions Atty Kronenwetter re: any statements made by the defendant that he has received have not been in violation and are admissible and were voluntary. 
Atty Kronenwetter concurs. 

Atty Kronenwetter makes arguments in support of his motion to adjourn. 
Atty Molepske makes arguments re: the motion. 
Atty Kronenwetter makes additional arguments. 
Court questions defendant re: understanding this will delay the trial. 
Defendant concurs. 

BY THE COURT:  Court finds the request is justified.  Motion to adjourn is granted.  Court will place this as a number 2 trial on 4/22 and 4/23.
Filing of other acts motions deadline will be 4/2/2015. If  there is a motion to be filed, parties to contact the judicial assistant for a hearing date. 

Atty Molepske makes statements.  Provided defense with 911 call that was made, today.  Requests the opportunity to play the 911 call at trial.  State is aware and did not bring motion, but will file additional motions to play the statements of jail house calls of the defendant.  
Court questions Atty Molepske. 
Atty Kronenwetter makes statements.  
Court questions Atty Molepske re: transcripts provided to the jury. 
Atty Molepske states he does intend to provide those to the jury to follow along.  
Atty Kronenwetter states he is requesting all calls of his client.  He will provide transcripts of the ones he may intend to call. 
Court questions if all tapes can be provided to the defendant by March 6th along with transcripts. 
Atty Molepske agrees. 
Court advises any objections to be done by motions. 

State is to draft the Order.  Jury trial scheduled for April 22, 2015 at 08:30 am.
and Writ of Habeas Corpus

No contact with Jeffrey Cueto, Tara Baker, *John Richert, his residence and place of employment,  Esteban Avila,  The Oxford House on Lindbergh Ave. (*amended name)
